content: Looking to learn how to work with rustc. It's a large codebase and there seems to be a lot to, well, learn, so I was hoping people could give some pointers. Also need to free up some disk space to actually build it in...

Hi! Check out https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/ and you can try to download LLVM on to your system rather than compiling it... uhm, sometimes this doesn't always work, since Rust uses a patched LLVM, but we're still working on shipping the patched LLVM inside bootstrap.
Is there a particular issue with building my own LLVM? It doesn't take too long and only uses 2 GiB or so of space.

oh if it's not too long for you then you're fine!
some people's machines uh, are not so beefy
Yea, that's understandable. The real problem is getting everything downloaded. I have exceptionally slow internet, so these kinds of projects suck to sync.
Oh yeah, then you're on the other side of the tradeoff and building is better for you.
having the download fail 68% of the way through is no fun at all...
this is the download of llvm?
No, of rustc's git repo.
My internet decided to die and I had to run down and screw with the router. Too late for git to recover from it though.
I really wish Git was able to recover from a partial clone and resume it.
a possible workaround is to start with a shallow clone and then fetch the history later: https://stackoverflow.com/a/3957733/7669110

or if you have tools for a resumable file download (maybe wget does this?) you could download a bundle: https://mirrors.edge.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/git-bundle.html. Not sure if github makes bundles publically available though
Alright, looking for possible beginners tasks.. any advice?
take a look at https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AE-easy or https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AE-mentor+
I should discuss an issue I'm considering picking up in the appropriate stream instead of here, correct?
I'd open a new thread in t-compiler/help, yeah
(or if it's general discussion and not help, t-compiler or #general )
Where might be the appropriate place to ask about rustfmt? looking at rustfmt/tests/source/cfg_if/detect/cache.rs and I think it could be refactored to use AtomicUSize

Hello! Welcome :)

According to https://github.com/rust-lang/rustfmt/blob/master/Contributing.md#contributing, rustfmt team is on the #WG-Rustfmt channel on Discord: https://discordapp.com/invite/rust-lang
Two PRs in, and I think this is kinda fun. I hope that's a good sign.
